Q4A: How do you describe yourself? (Check one)

Q5: Did you work as a Geriatric Resource Nurse (GRN) prior to becoming the NICHE Coordinator at your organization?
Q6: Are you certified by the American Nurses Credentialing Center (ANCC) in Gerontological Nursing?
Q7: Are you certified in a clinical specialty other than Gerontological Nursing?

Q8A: Nurse Practitioner Certifications (Check all that apply)
Q8B: Clinical Nurse Specialist Certifications (Check all that apply)
Q8C: Specialty Certifications for Registered Nurses (Check all that apply)

Q9A: In what Advanced Practice nursing role are you prepared?

Q11: On a weekly basis, what percent of your time is devoted to clinical practice responsibilities?
Q12: On average, how many hours per week do you spend leading and managing the NICHEprogram at your organization?
Q14: As the NICHE Coordinator, are you a member of a hospital-wide committee (or other governing body) responsible for clinical practice and policy development?
Q15: As the NICHE Coordinator, are you a member of a hospital-wide committee (or other governing body) responsible for improving the quality of care for older adults?
Q16: Is your role as the NICHE Coordinator clear to you?
Q17: Is your role as the NICHE Coordinator clear to other staff?
Q18_1: In your role as the NICHE Coordinator, how confident are you with carrying out the following activities? - Mentoring staff nurses in the Geriatric Resource Nurse (GRN) role?
Q18_2: In your role as the NICHE Coordinator, how confident are you with carrying out the following activities? - Acting as a preceptor for other NICHE Coordinators?
Q18_3: In your role as the NICHE Coordinator, how confident are you with carrying out the following activities? - Translating clinical research on the care of older adults to improve clinical practice?
Q18_4: In your role as the NICHE Coordinator, how confident are you with carrying out the following activities? - Reviewing the performance on NICHE units to assess risks to clients' safety?
Q18_5: In your role as the NICHE Coordinator, how confident are you with carrying out the following activities? - Reviewing the performance on NICHE units to assess risks to the quality of care?
Q18_6: In your role as the NICHE Coordinator, how confident are you with carrying out the following activities? - Using evidence to challenge existing practices in the care of older adults?
Q18_7: In your role as the NICHE Coordinator, how confident are you with carrying out the following activities? - Communicating evidence-based practice modification for the care of older adults to other health professionals?
Q18_8: In your role as the NICHE Coordinator, how confident are you with carrying out the following activities? - Providing clinical leadership to the staff nurses implementing the Geriatric Resource Nurse (GRN) model in your organization?
Q18_9: In your role as the NICHE Coordinator, how confident are you with carrying out the following activities? - Providing leadership to support staff involved in implementing the NICHE program principles in your organization?
Q19: How many units are piloting the GRN model in your organization?

Q32_1: V. General Views on the NICHE Program Implementation - This hospital’s financial constraints have made it difficult to offer as much staff training on the care of older adults as needed.
Q32_2: V. General Views on the NICHE Program Implementation - We have had to implement the NICHE program on a tight budget.
Q32_3: V. General Views on the NICHE Program Implementation - Adequate funds are available to finance this hospital’s NICHE Program implementation efforts.
Q32_4: V. General Views on the NICHE Program Implementation - Most nurses are so busy that they have little time to devote to NICHE program implementation.
Q32_5: V. General Views on the NICHE Program Implementation - Staff are encouraged to take time off from their regular work tasks to attend NICHE program meetings and training sessions.
Q32_6: V. General Views on the NICHE Program Implementation - The nurse administrators (unit managers, supervisors, senior managers) are strongly committed to the successful implementation of the NICHE program.
Q32_7: V. General Views on the NICHE Program Implementation - The nurse administrators (unit managers, supervisors, senior managers) take an active interest in the NICHE program problems and successes.
Q32_8: V. General Views on the NICHE Program Implementation - The NICHE program Leadership Training Program taught me what I need to know about implementing NICHE at my hospital.
Q32_9: V. General Views on the NICHE Program Implementation - Training is readily available to staff who want to learn more about the care of older adults.
Q32_10: V. General Views on the NICHE Program Implementation - Supervisors praise staff participating in the NICHE program.
Q32_11: V. General Views on the NICHE Program Implementation - Staff understand why the hospital is implementing the NICHE program on the nursing units.
Q32_12: V. General Views on the NICHE Program Implementation - NICHE is a top priority at this hospital.
Q32_13: V. General Views on the NICHE Program Implementation - People put a lot of effort into making NICHE a success here.
Q32_14: V. General Views on the NICHE Program Implementation - People at this hospital think that the implementation of NICHE is important.
Q32_15: V. General Views on the NICHE Program Implementation - I think this hospital made a good decision by joining NICHE.
Q32_16: V. General Views on the NICHE Program Implementation - I think that NICHE is an improvement over the way that we used to care for older adults.
Q32_17: V. General Views on the NICHE Program Implementation - My NICHE Coordinator position is like a second job.
Q32_18: V. General Views on the NICHE Program Implementation - My current level of education prepared me well to work as a NICHE Coordinator.

Q23_4_TEXT: Interdisciplinary patient case presentations and discussions based on SPICES screening
Q50: A change for staff to incorporate the additional assessment and documentation. A challenge for them to complete the assessments due to the very rapid turnover of patients on the unit. Patient confusion was often a barrier to being able to adequately assess patients for all frailty risks. No major barriers were encountered. We have attempted to obtain approval for GPCA from the CDPH with the process being so largely involved, we have not been able to offer our CNAs the program with granted CEUs.
Q51: All staff on pilot unit attended mandatory inservice training regarding care of the Geriatric population in the acute inpatient setting to include training on SPICES & Frailty Assessments/Interventions; and documentation procedures. Positive support from various disciplines participating in patient care planning discussions. Expert guest lectures on topics such as delirium; dementia; depression; Polypharmacy; Beers Meds. Funds provided for 3 Staff nurses to attend 2018 NICHE Conference; 1 of which presented an oral presentation. IT Support for developing targeted Frailty Assessment/Intervention documentation. Our institution has significant interest in providing safe care for the elderly population demonstrated by our recent 5 Star CMS rating. Heightened interest was observed  t/o the organization having approx. 40 nurses complete the GRN course in the first year.
Q52: Tremendous assist if NICHE Office could provide reports of the numbers of nurses who are granted access to the GRN course and status of completion on a regular basis.

Q50: The barriers to implementing the NICHE program include the hospital's primary focus to become part of a national health care system.  Several changes and time sensitive imperitives have taken priority.  Another challenge has been my transition to NICHE coordinator from my full time focus as more of an adult - gero CNS as I have been in the first role for nearly 10 years.
Q51: Shared leadership council leaders have voiced support as well as the Med-Surg Nursing Director and the Professional Practice Nursing Director.  Physicians and Advanced Practice Providers who developed and use the geriatric order sets for G60 and Frailty Fracture patients support NICHE.
Q52: During the first two years of implementation - provide formal scheduled 1:1 calls pairing experienced NICHE coordinators with the new NICHE coordinators.  The Leaderhip Training Program was a whirlwind of tight deadlines and reading which gave little practical implementation support.

Q51: Senior level management along with support and engagement of Patient Care Managers and Clinical Educators has been outstanding.
Q52: Attention to or more information about how to implement a NICHE program in coordination with other senior friendly projects would be helpful.  Questions in this survey and information from the program are generally discussed in a way that implies there are no other senior friendly projects underway making it challenging to follow the path suggested by NICHE for implementation and reporting.

Q50: Financial constraints disallow dedicated time for the training.  Even if trained, our care model does not allow for GRNs to act as consultants for others, as all nurses in clinical care have a patient assignment that would not allow them to leave their own patients.
Q51: CNO and unit director and managers are very supportive, but also understand the financial constraints.  We continue to improve the care of our elderly patients through QI efforts even if not named "NICHE" specific.
Q52: It would be nice to get our GIAP results, this may help drive what is needed specifically.
